Title: DESENVOLVIMENTO DE NÉCTARES MISTOS À BASE DE CAJU (Anacardium occidentale L) E AÇAÍ (Euterpe oleracea Mart.)
Methodology: A central composite design 2^2 was used to optimize a mixed nectar of cashew and açaí, with variables including açaí pulp percentage (20-80%), cashew juice percentage (20-80%), and total pulp percentage (30-60%), fixing total soluble solids at 11°Brix. Eleven formulations were assessed using sensory tests for overall impression, appearance, flavor, and purchase intent, with statistical analysis of response surfaces.
Key Findings: The best formulation comprised 30.0% total pulp, with 54.2% açaí pulp and 45.8% cashew juice. Chemical and physicochemical analyses showed no significant interaction between packaging and storage time, except for total sugars. Sensory evaluation revealed no significant differences between PET and glass packaging over 30 days. Microbiological results for coliforms and Salmonella sp. were satisfactory.

Title: EFEITO DO EXTRATO DO BAGAÇO DO PEDÚNCULO DE CAJU (Anacardium occidentale L.) CONTRA Streptococcus mutans
Methodology: The study aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial and antibiofilm potential of hydroalcoholic extract from cashew peduncle bagasse (EBPC) against Streptococcus mutans. It determined the Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC), Minimum Bactericidal Concentration (MBC), and assessed biofilm formation inhibition through biomass quantification using the S. mutans strain.
Key Findings: The EBPC showed bacteriostatic (MIC = 250 µg.mL-1) and bactericidal (MBC = 1000 µg.mL-1) action against S. mutans. It also inhibited biofilm biomass at a minimum concentration of 250 µg.mL-1. The study concluded that EBPC exhibits antimicrobial and antibiofilm activity against S. mutans, suggesting its potential as a biotechnological product for dentistry.

Title: DESENVOLVIMENTO DE BEBIDA VEGETAL À BASE DE AMÊNDOA DE CASTANHA DE CAJU (Anacardium occidentale L.), ARROZ (Oryza sativa L.) E AMEIXA (Prunus domestica L.)
Beverage Type: Vegetable beverage based on almond cashew nut, rice and plum
Methodology: Four formulations were developed using a 22 factorial design, varying the proportions of cashew nut (3% and 6%) and plum (9% and 12%). The beverages were analyzed for physical-chemical characteristics, carotenoid content, antioxidant activity, viscosity, reology, color, fatty acid profile, and microbiological parameters. Sensory evaluation was performed using acceptance test with hedonic scale.
Key Findings: The study concluded that the development of a new vegetable beverage based on rice, cashew nut, and plums is viable. Different concentrations of plum and cashew nut enabled the production of a product with an excellent source of nutrients, a good lipid profile, microbiologically safe, and sensorially accepted.

Title: AVALIAÇÃO SENSORIAL E CARACTERIZAÇÃO DE CERVEJA DE TRIGO ADICIONADA DE PSEUDOFRUTO DO CAJU (ANACARDIUM OCCIDENTALE) E CASCAS DE LARANJA (CITRUS SINENSIS)
Methodology: Four wheat beer formulations were evaluated: a control, one with 10% cashew pseudofruit, one with 0.6% orange peel, and one with both cashew (10%) and orange peel (0.6%).  Physico-chemical (moisture, ash, carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, energy value, total acidity, pH, alcohol content, density, and primitive, real, and apparent extracts) and sensory analyses were performed, along with microbiological assessments.
Key Findings: The addition of orange peels and cashew pseudofruit as adjuncts resulted in strong (original extracts ≥ 14%), acidic (0.22 g acetic acid/100ml), alcoholic (5.23%), and fruity beers. The addition of cashew contributed to increased acidity, lower pH (4.12), higher alcoholic content (5.17%), and higher original (23.23%) and apparent (32.13%) extracts. Sensorial analysis showed all formulations had positive acceptance, but the fruit additions did not significantly differentiate the formulations from the control.

Title: AVALIAÇÃO DA TOXICIDADE DE SUCO DE CAJU (Anacardium occidentale) PROCESSADO POR PLASMA FRIO E ULTRASSOM
Methodology: Acute toxicity and protective effect tests were performed on unprocessed and non-thermally processed cashew juice using Artemia salina nauplii. The resulting samples were investigated for mortality, oxidative enzymes, and morphology.
Key Findings: There was no mortality of nauplii exposed to non-processed and sonicated cashew juice. However, plasmolized samples provoked deaths at 1000 μg/mL. Sonicated sample was the only sample that presented a protective effect against hydrogen peroxide stress.

Title: EFEITO DO SUCO DE CAJU (Anacardium occidentale L.) ADICIONADO DE FARINHAS DO BAGAÇO DE CAJU SOBRE A RESPOSTA IMUNOLÓGICA EM CAMUNDONGOS
Beverage Type: Cashew juice with added cashew bagasse flour
Methodology: The study evaluated the phytochemical composition, total antioxidant potential, and immunomodulatory activity of cashew apple juice with added mature (SFM) and immature (SFV) bagasse flour in mice. The antioxidant capacity of juice and flour was assessed using ABTS and DPPH methods. In vivo tests involved treating mice with different doses of SFM and SFV, followed by assessment of physiological parameters, humoral and cellular immune responses using sheep red blood cells (SRBC).
Key Findings: Cashew green bagasse flour exhibited the highest antioxidant capacity and polyphenol levels. The cashew juice and SFV at 300 mg/kg showed higher antibody titers in the humoral response. In the cellular response, juice, SFM and SFV (300 mg/kg) induced increased delayed type hypersensitivity (DTH).

Title: ESTUDO CINÉTICO DA FERMENTAÇÃO DE KEFIR E KOMBUCHA EM EXTRATO HIDROSSOLÚVEL DE AMÊNDOA DE CASTANHA DE CAJU (Anacardium Occidentale L.)
Beverage Type: Fermented drink (kefir and kombucha) from cashew nuts
Methodology: The kinetic of fermentation of kefir and kombucha in cashew nut extract was studied. The beverage was formulated with 10% of dried raw cashew nuts, pasteurized by the HTLT method and three samples were formulated: LC-F (100% kefir), LC-B (100% kombucha) and LC-FB (50% kefir and 50% kombucha). The samples were analyzed with 0, 4, 8, 12, 24, 36, 48 and 72 hours of fermentation at 28 ºC, monitoring pH, soluble solids, titratable acidity, sugars and organic acids, as well as acute toxicity and locomotor activity of zebrafish.
Key Findings: LC-B showed slower changes with time, while LC-F and LC-FB showed greater speed in their reactions with similar curves. LC-F and LC-FB exhausted carbohydrate reserves within 48 hours, but LC-FB was more efficient in the consumption of oligosaccharides. The mixture of kefir and kombucha presents a more efficient sugar hydrolysis dynamic, including larger molecules, but requires further investigation to confirm probiotic activity.

Title: ESTUDO QUTMICO E TECNOLÓGICO DO CAJU (Anacardium occidentale L.)
Methodology: The study examined the physical, chemical, physico-chemical, and microbiological characteristics of cashew peduncles and nuts over ten weeks of harvesting. It also assessed the stability of cashew nectar over 180 days and transformations in cashew nuts stored under industrial conditions for 120 days.
Key Findings: The research indicated consistent characteristics of cashew peduncles and nuts throughout the harvesting period.  Oleic acid (65%), linoleic acid (17.80%), and palmitic acid (9.40%) were the predominant fatty acids in cashew almond composition.  Cashew nectar, stored at ambient temperature for six months, demonstrated good chemical and microbiological stability.

Title: [Estudo sobre Anacardium occidentale L.]: INFLUÊNCIA DE CONDIÇÕES OPERACIONAIS
Methodology: The study evaluated the production of ethanol from cashew juice, assessing the influence of temperature on the kinetics of ethanol production. Different microorganisms were evaluated, and the impact of the initial concentration of carbohydrates (glucose and fructose) in the cashew juice was studied, applying mathematical models to describe the kinetics.
Key Findings: The study concluded that cashew juice is a suitable substrate for ethanol production.  The use of cashew juice will not only bring economic benefits to the process, because it is a low-cost substrate, but will also bring environmental benefits, since it is an agro-industrial waste from cashew nut production. The best temperature range for fermentation was between 30 and 38°C.

Title: ATIVIDADES ANTIOXIDANTE, ANTI-INFLAMATÓRIA E CICATRIZANTE DO CAJU (Anacardium occidentale L.)
Methodology: The study evaluated the antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and wound-healing activities of cashew juice in vitro and in vivo.  In vitro, total polyphenol content, ascorbic acid, total anthocyanins, yellow flavonoids, carotenoids, phenolic compounds, and total antioxidant activity were determined. In vivo, the anti-inflammatory effect was assessed using the xylene-induced ear edema model in mice, and wound healing was evaluated by inducing lesions on the backs of mice after supplementation with cashew juices.
Key Findings: The phytochemical profile differed between green and ripe cashew juice, with ripe cashew juice showing higher levels of non-enzymatic antioxidants and total antioxidant capacity. Green cashew juice efficiently reduced inflammation and accelerated wound healing during the intermediate phase compared to ripe cashew juice, while ripe cashew juice seemed to act in the later stages of healing.

Title: EFEITO DO PROCESSAMENTO SOBRE CARACTERÍSTICAS DE QUALIDADE DO SUCO DE CAJU (Anacardium occidentale L.)
Methodology: The study analyzed three batches of cashew juice after formulation, homogenization, and pasteurization stages. Determinations included acidity, pH, total soluble solids, reducing, non-reducing and total sugars, water activity (Aw), carotenoids, anthocyanins, ascorbic acid, and folic acid; a specific analytical methodology was developed for folic acid.
Key Findings: Total soluble solids, acidity, water activity, vitamins, and pigments varied significantly during processing. Ascorbic acid, carotenoid, and anthocyanin losses were highest during pasteurization.  Folic acid exhibited significant variation between formulation and homogenization stages.

Title: EFEITO PREBIÓTICO DE SUCO DE CAJU (Anacardium occidentale) CONTENDO GLICO-OLIGOSSACARÍDEOS, DEXTRANA E TAGATOSE
Beverage Type: Cashew juice containing glyco-oligosaccharides, dextran, and tagatose
Methodology: The prebiotic oligosaccharides were synthesized in cashew juice using dextran-sucrase enzyme (30 °C / 17 h). In vitro digestion simulation was conducted at 37 °C/6 h, evaluating the concentration of glyco-oligosaccharides, dextran, and tagatose, and vitamin C bioaccessibility. The prebiotic effect was assessed using Lactobacillus casei, Bifidobacterium breve, and Bifidobacterium infantis.
Key Findings: Oligosaccharides, tagatose, and part of dextran (70-90%) resisted gastrointestinal conditions, reaching the final part of the digestive system where probiotic microorganisms consume prebiotic carbohydrates. Prebiotic juices improved vitamin C bioaccessibility, suggesting a protective effect. The prebiotic ingredients stimulated the growth of bifidobacteria and lactobacilli, with tagatose benefiting B. infantis, and dextran and oligosaccharides benefiting L. casei and B. breve, respectively.

Title: Elaboração, Caracterização Físico-Química e Avaliação da Capacidade Antioxidante de Cerveja de Trigo Adicionada de Pseudofruto de Caju (Anacardium Occidenale) e Casca de Laranja (Citrus Sinensis)
Methodology: A wheat beer was developed with the addition of cashew peduncle and orange peel by the craft process. The bark concentrations were 0 and 0.6 % (m/m) and cashew, 0, 5 and 10 % (m/m), resulting in six different combinations. The raw materials were characterized by physico-chemical assessment and added to the fermentation phase. The formulations were subjected to low fermentation, maturation and carbonation.
Key Findings: The use of cashew peduncle and orange peel in the preparation of craft beers is feasible. The formulation number six, containing 10% cashew pseudofruit (m/m) and 0.6% orange peel (m/m), presented the most satisfactory results. Those containing higher levels of cashew demonstrated to be more acidic, with largest percentage of phenolic compounds and antioxidant activity.

Authors: Érica Milô de Freitas Felipe Rocha
Title: DESIDRATAÇÃO DE POLPA DE MANGA E SUCO DE CAJU INTEGRAL POR ATOMIZAÇÃO E CARACTERIZAÇÃO DOS PRODUTOS OBTIDOS
Methodology: Mango pulp and cashew juice were dehydrated using a spray-dryer. The influence of process conditions on the yield and moisture content of the powders was evaluated through experimental designs. The powders were characterized for physicochemical and hygroscopic properties, and stability was assessed during 180 days of storage under different packaging.
Key Findings: The drying process yielded good quality powders with desirable physicochemical and hygroscopic properties. Sorption isotherms were type III, indicating high sugar content. Henderson model best fit the data. Laminated packaging provided better protection during storage.

Title: EFEITO ESOFAGOPROTETOR DE UM BIOPOLÍMERO, A GOMA DO CAJUEIRO, NA DOENÇA DO REFLUXO NÃO-EROSIVA EM MURINOS E EM BIÓPSIAS ESOFÁGICAS HUMANAS: PERFIL ANTI-INFLAMATÓRIO E EFEITO TÓPICO
Methodology: The study evaluated the esophagoprotective effect of cashew gum (CG) in mice with non-erosive reflux disease (NERD) and in human esophageal biopsies. The experimental design included a pre-clinical study with murine NERD induced surgically and a clinical study with human esophageal biopsies, assessing inflammation, barrier function, and toxicity.
Key Findings: Cashew gum exhibited anti-inflammatory properties by reducing edema and inflammatory cell infiltration in the esophagus. It also showed protective effects by preserving esophageal mucosal integrity, sustaining transepithelial electrical resistance, and preventing increased transepithelial permeability. Furthermore, cashew gum demonstrated strong mucoadhesive properties, forming an extra shield on the pre-epithelial layer.

Title: CARACTERIZAÇÃO E ESTUDO DA APLICABILIDADE DO BIOSSURFACTANTE PRODUZIDO POR Bacillus subtilis LAMI005 A PARTIR DO SUCO DE CAJU
Methodology: The biosurfactant produced by Bacillus subtilis LAMI005 was characterized using cashew apple juice as a carbon source. The study involved investigating the conformation and structure of the compounds to determine the functional groups of the molecule, assessing the toxicological effects of the surfactin produced, and evaluating the maintenance of the tensioactive characteristics of surfactin under different environmental conditions.
Key Findings: Spectra indicated similarity between the surfactin produced and standard surfactin. The lipopeptide exhibited highly stable surface activity, with a CMC of 12.5 mg/L, reducing water surface tension to 31.8 mN/m and n-hexadecane interfacial tension to 2 mN/m. The biosurfactant also demonstrated non-toxicity towards Artemia salina and Lactuca sativa, suggesting its potential in cosmetics, food, and pharmaceutical industries, and it efficiently removed diesel and petroleum from sand.

Title: DESENVOLVIMENTO DE UMA BEBIDA FERMENTADA À BASE DE XERÉM DE CASTANHA DE CAJU (Anacardium occidentale L.)
Methodology: The study aimed to develop a fermented plant-based beverage using cashew nut residue (xerém) and evaluate its functional potential. The beverage was fermented with Lacticaseibacillus casei NRRL B-442, and its stability was assessed over 42 days under refrigeration, monitoring pH, viability, lactic acid, and sugar concentrations.  Sensory analysis was performed using word association, hedonic scale, and CATA tests.
Key Findings: The L. casei NRRL B-442 strain effectively fermented the cashew nut residue, demonstrating a preference for glucose consumption and lactic acid production. The fermented beverage remained stable throughout the 42-day refrigerated storage, maintaining high viable cell counts and undergoing post-acidification. Sensory analysis indicated good acceptance of the beverage, with no significant differences between sucrose and sucralose-sweetened samples.

Title: Processamento de suco de caju (Anacardium occidentale) por tecnologias não térmicas: efeitos nas características físico-químicas e compostos bioativos
Methodology: The effects of ultrasound, ozone, and pulsed light on the bioactive compounds and physicochemical characteristics of cashew juice were studied and compared to the effects of heat treatment. Ultrasound (372.93 W/cm2; 20 °C; 10 min), ozone (0.24 mgO3/mL), and pulsed light (1 J/cm2) were applied to the cashew juice.
Key Findings: Ultrasound increased the antioxidant capacity of cashew juice, while heat treatment decreased it. Ozone preserved antioxidant activity but decreased flavonoids and vitamin C. Pulsed light increased antioxidant activity and preserved flavonoids and vitamin C concentrations.  These non-thermal technologies can be used alone or combined with other treatments in the processing of cashew juice to better preserve its natural characteristics.

Title: PROCESSAMENTO DE FIBRA DE CAJU POR EXTRAÇÃO DE SUBSTÂNCIAS SOLÚVEIS SEGUIDA DE SECAGEM PARA APLICAÇÃO COMO INGREDIENTE EM PRODUTO PLANT-BASED
Methodology: Cashew fiber was pre-treated by extraction of soluble substances with sequential cycles of hydration with water, pressing, and drying. The study compared drying processes using a forced air circulation oven and freeze-drying and applied the pre-treated fiber in a plant-based croquette-type product. Sensory evaluation, physical, and physicochemical analyses were conducted on the fiber and croquettes.
Key Findings: The sensory perception of cashew flavor in the fiber is weak after the second cycle of hydration and pressing, suggesting that the number of cycles can be reduced. Freeze-drying equipment obtained the best drying results.  Croquettes with up to 40% cashew fiber were well-accepted, while those with 50% fiber had a perceptible cashew flavor.

Title: Undefined
Methodology: Undefined
Key Findings: Undefined

Authors: A. P. de Oliveira, J. E. da Silva, N. Narain
Title: Cashew apple juice: processing, technological aspects, composition, and nutritional properties
Methodology: Review article.
Key Findings: This review discusses cashew apple processing, technological aspects, composition, and nutritional properties.

Title: DESENVOLVIMETO DE UMA BEBIDA FUNCIONAL A BASE DE CAJU (Anacardium occidentale L.) COM Lactobacillus casei DN 114-001 LIVRE E MICROENCAPSULADO
Beverage Type: Functional cashew drink with Lactobacillus casei (free and microencapsulated)
Methodology: A functional cashew beverage was developed with Lactobacillus casei, free or microencapsulated with a calcium alginate-chitosan matrix.  Microcapsules were prepared by the emulsion/internal gelation method, with alginate as the encapsulating agent and subsequent coating of the spheres with chitosan.
Key Findings: During simulated gastrointestinal conditions, free L. casei lost all viability, while encapsulated cells showed resistance.  After 28 days of storage, beverages containing microcapsules and free cells presented 10.2 and 8.1 log CFU/mL, respectively. Sensory analysis demonstrated that the drinks were accepted by the judges, despite the microspheres having been perceived.

Title: DESENVOLVIMENTO E CARACTERIZAÇÃO DE BEBIDA COM POTENCIAL PROBIÓTICO À BASE DE EXTRATO HIDROSSOLÚVEL DE CASTANHA DE CAJU (Anacardium occidentale L.)
Beverage Type: Probiotic drink based on cashew hydrosoluble extract
Methodology: Cashew hydrosoluble extract (EHCC) was fermented with the probiotic strain Lb. paracasei ATCC 334 using a 2^2 factorial design. The independent variables were the concentration of Lb. paracasei (1%, 1.5%, and 2%) and cashew nuts (100g, 200g, and 300g), and the dependent variables were moisture, lipids, proteins, ash, carbohydrates, and sensory acceptance attributes.
Key Findings: The concentration of Lb. paracasei in EHCC reached 7.72 to 8.27 Log CFU/g after 6 hours of fermentation, indicating probiotic potential.  Cashew nut concentration significantly influenced physicochemical parameters and sensory attributes. The study suggests fermented EHCC is potentially capable of meeting probiotic demand for individuals with milk-restrictive diets.

Title: Métodos de redução da adstringência de pedúnculos de caju in natura e seus efeitos sobre a qualidade físico-química, nutricional e aromática
Methodology: The study involved treating cashew peduncles with ethanol vapor, carbon dioxide, and modified atmosphere packaging (MAP) using different films (PA/PE and BOPP). The physical-chemical, nutritional, and aromatic qualities were analyzed during storage at 5°C.
Key Findings: Ethanol vapor, carbon dioxide and MAP treatments reduce astringency.  BOPP films are effective for reducing astringency and preserving quality without fermentation. Destanization affects antioxidant activity and specific nutritional compounds.

Title: Aplicação do subproduto de caju (Anacardium occidentale) em leite fermentado probiótico: compostos bioativos, avaliação de grupos bacterianos no armazenamento, digestão e impacto na microbiota intestinal
Methodology: The study evaluated the physicochemical aspects of dehydrated cashew by-product (SC), its application in fermented milk with pre-selected probiotics and starters, and the impact of the formulations on the intestinal microbiota.  The survival of the strains into the formulations were accessed in gastrointestinal (GI) conditions in a static and a dynamic GI model, the latter using a Simulator of the Human Intestinal Microbial Ecosystem (SEMH).
Key Findings: The dehydrated cashew by-product resulted in good viability of  L. paracasei F-19 in fermented milk and increased antioxidant activity and phenolic compounds as well.  The presence of FT in the reactors incremented in CFT and AA and presence of rumenic acid and linolênic acid.  Association subproduct of cashew and probiotic (F-19) in formulated fermented milk can be a synergistic simbiotic.

Authors: Marion de Araújo Beda, Priscila Strauss Pereira Soares
Title: DIAMOND: EMBALAGEM INDIVIDUAL PARA BEBIDAS DESTILADAS
Methodology: The project involved research on consumer behavior, preferences, and opinions regarding distilled beverage consumption, focusing on individual packaging. Based on this research, a concept was developed aimed at innovating the market and strengthening niche sales, particularly in informal street commerce.
Key Findings: The research identified a demand for individual distilled beverage packaging, especially in environments where using glasses is impractical.  The designed packaging is modern, youthful, simple, and intended for immediate individual consumption. It caters to young, independent consumers seeking novelty, fun, and status.

Title: AVALIAÇÃO DE PARÂMETROS FÍSICO – QUÍMICOS DE COR E ROTULAGEM EM NECTARES E SUCOS CONCENTRADOS DE CAJU.
Methodology: Market analysis was conducted in Macaé to select three brands each of concentrated cashew juice and cashew nectar, categorized by price (high, medium, low). Analyses included total solids, soluble solids in Brix°, pH, ascorbic acid content, and color analysis, following established methodologies.
Key Findings: Some samples differed from Brazilian legislation's Identity and Quality Standards, but vitamin C content was within recommended levels. Label analysis revealed irregularities, such as a quality seal on Maguary® concentrated juice and the absence of 'ready to drink' on nectar labels, potentially misleading consumers.

Title: DESENVOLVIMENTO DE CONSERVANTES ANTIMICROBIANOS DE BASE NATURAL E AVALIAÇÃO DE DESEMPENHO EM BEBIDAS NÃO ALCOÓLICAS
Methodology: The study aimed to analyze the potential of microalgae biomass (Spirulina, Chlorella, Scenedesmus, Haematococcus) and natural substances (calcium levulinate, p-anisic acid) as natural antimicrobial preservatives in orange juice and nectar. The methodology involved selecting microalgae strains and substances, preparing culture media, seeding beverage samples, identifying microorganisms using MALDI-TOF MS, and testing the efficiency of preservatives in inhibiting microbial growth through halo formation analysis and membrane filtration.
Key Findings: The study identified Chlorella sp, Spirulina maxima, p-anisic acid, and levulinic acid as promising natural preservatives for non-alcoholic beverages.  Specific concentrations of these substances were effective in reducing microbial growth in orange nectar and refreshment drinks.  The findings suggest potential alternatives to synthetic preservatives for enhancing the hygienic-sanitary quality of industrialized beverages.

Authors: Felipe Batista Hawad, Thalmo Uriel Paula de Azevedo
Title: Estudo de viabilidade técnica e econômica de uma fábrica de sidra artesanal no Estado do Rio de Janeiro
Methodology: A technical and economic feasibility analysis was conducted for an artisanal cider factory with a production capacity of 4,000 liters per month in Petrópolis, Rio de Janeiro. The study calculated the necessary investment, production costs, economic indicators (Internal Rate of Return, Net Present Value, Payback Time), and break-even point, along with sensitivity and scenario analyses, based on a production route starting from clarified apple juice.
Key Findings: The analyses indicated that the project is economically viable, with attractive return indicators. However, the enterprise showed high sensitivity to factors associated with product acceptance, such as the selling price, highlighting the project's high level of risk.

Title: Aplicação de ferramentas de identificação molecular para micro-organismos importantes em processos fermentativos na área de alimentos
Methodology: The study employs a systematic review of scientific articles and other sources to gather data on controlling the quality of microorganisms used in food production and the resulting products. It also proposes the application of molecular biology tools in this context.
Key Findings: The research indicates that molecular biology techniques are valuable for the food industry, yet their adoption remains limited. The systematic review showed that molecular methods can identify and elucidate the microbiota involved in wine and beer fermentation, demonstrating a close relationship between these microorganisms and the sensory quality of the products.

Authors: Yaw Gyau Akyereko, Georgina Benewaa Yeboah, Faustina Dufie Wireko‐Manu, Francis Alemawor, Felix Charles Mills-Robertson, William Odoom
Title: Nutritional value and health benefits of cashew apple
Methodology: The study reviewed recent articles on the nutritional composition and health benefits of cashew apples. This was done to improve accessibility and readership of existing information.
Key Findings: Cashew apples contain significant amounts of vitamin C, sugars (fructose and sucrose), fibers, flavonoids, carotenoids, total polyphenols, volatile components, flavanols, amino acids, and minerals, such as potassium, magnesium, sodium, and iron. These contribute to maintaining strong immunity, scavenging free radicals, neuropathic and cardiac functioning, and body and skin integrity. Cashew apple consumption and its value-added products may offer therapeutic benefits for managing diabetes and cardiovascular diseases.

Authors: Lou Boli Caroline Sahie, Doudjo Soro, Kisselmina Youssouf Kone, Nogbou Emmanuel Assidjo, Kouassi Benjamin Yao
Title: Some Processing Steps and Uses of Cashew Apples: A Review
Methodology: This review paper discusses cashew tree cultivation and the existing literature on cashew juice. It highlights the physicochemical characteristics of cashew apples, the impact of growing area, variety, and maturity on these characteristics, and the influence of processing steps on nutritional value and organoleptic quality.
Key Findings: The cashew apple is nutritionally rich and possesses technological advantages due to its high edible portion, juicy flesh, and large availability. The review covers methods of clarification, stabilization, concentration, and dehydration. Some uses of cashew apple were reviewed: beverage, food, substrate, bioethanol, nutraceutical, food additive and agro materials.

Authors: Geraldo Arraes Maia, William H. Brown, F. Whiting, J.W. Stull
Title: Cashew Fatty Acids1
Methodology: Lipids were isolated from cashew nut using silicic acid column chromatography to analyze fatty acid distributions. Comparative esterification methods were used to identify free lauric acid in cashew apple juice.
Key Findings: Cashew apple juice contains significant amounts of free lauric acid. Oleic and linoleic acids occur in almost identical amounts in cashew nut testa, while oleic acid predominates in the kernel. Fatty acid distributions in pulp and peel from red and yellow cultivars of cashew apple at immature and mature stages show differences, with oleic acid increasing during maturation and linoleic and linolenic acids decreasing.

Authors: Evanie Devi Deenanath, Sunny E. Iyuke, Karl Rumbold
Title: The Bioethanol Industry in Sub-Saharan Africa: History, Challenges, and Prospects
Methodology: The paper examines the history and challenges of bioethanol production in sub-Saharan Africa and demonstrates the bioethanol production potential, focusing on using cashew apple juice as an unconventional feedstock.
Key Findings: The paper highlights the potential of cashew apple juice as an unconventional feedstock for bioethanol production in sub-Saharan Africa. It also discusses the historical context and challenges faced by the bioethanol industry in the region.

Authors: Marc Adou, Yao Desiré Adjouman, Kouadio Olivier Kouadio, Achille Fabrice Tetchi, N’Guessan Georges Amani
Title: Improvement of Cashew Apple Juice (&lt;i&gt;Anacardium occidentale&lt;/i&gt; L.) by Association with Passion Fruit Juice (&lt;i&gt;Passiflora edulis&lt;/i&gt;)
Methodology: Mixed juice formulations of cashew apple and passion fruit juice were created in varying proportions. Sensory evaluations were conducted to determine the most appreciated formulation.
Key Findings: A mixed juice formulation (E) with 90 mL passion fruit juice and 10 mL cashew apple juice was found to be more palatable with improved sensory characteristics. The addition of passion fruit juice helped reduce the astringency of raw cashew apple juice, leading to higher overall acceptance. Formulation E is recommended to improve the organoleptic properties of cashew apple juice.

Title: Otimização de sistema de fermentação alcoolica continua utilizando reatores tipo torre e leveduras com caracteristicas floculantes
Methodology: The study optimized a continuous alcoholic fermentation system using tower reactors and flocculating yeasts.
Key Findings: The abstract discusses the optimization of different reactor arrangements (Arranjo 1, 2, and 3) focusing on yield and productivity, and defining the optimal operating range for each arrangement. Specific results are not detailed in this abstract.

Authors: Bahare Salehi, Mine Gültekin‐Özgüven, Celale Kırkın, Beraat Özçelik, Maria Flaviana Bezerra Morais‐Braga, Joara Nályda Pereira Carneiro, Camila Fonseca Bezerra, Teresinha Gonçalves da Silva, Henrique Douglas Melo Coutinho, Amina Benabdallah, Lorene Armstrong, Zeliha Selamoğlu, Мustafa Sevindik, Zubaida Yousaf, Javad Sharifi‐Rad, Ali Mahmoud Muddathir, Hari Prasad Devkota, Miquel Martorell, Arun K. Jugran, William C. Cho, Natália Martins
Title: Antioxidant, Antimicrobial, and Anticancer Effects of Anacardium Plants: An Ethnopharmacological Perspective
Methodology: The article reviews the biological effects of Anacardium plants, with a focus on their antioxidant, antimicrobial, and anticancer activities. It emphasizes their pharmacological and clinical efficacy to potentially stimulate further research.
Key Findings: The review highlights the increasing recognition of Anacardium plants for their nutritional and biological properties, specifically their antioxidant, antimicrobial, and anticancer activities. It suggests further studies on their therapeutic properties with clinical trials.

Authors: Leandro Fernandes Damasceno, Fabiano A.N. Fernandes, M. M. A. Magalhães, Edy Sousa de Brito
Title: Evaluation and optimization of non enzymatic browning of “cajuina” during thermal treatment
Methodology: The effect of thermal treatment on cajuina (clarified cashew apple juice) was studied at temperatures from 88°C to 121°C. Changes in color, vitamin C, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) and sugar content were measured to evaluate non enzymatic browning.
Key Findings: Kinetic models were used to optimize the thermal treatment to produce cajuina with an absorbance at 420 nm of 0.023.

Authors: Érica Milô Freitas Felipe Rocha, Sanyelle Lima Sousa, Janaína de Paula da Costa, Suelí Rodrigues, Marcos Rodrigues Amorim Afonso, José M. C. da Costa
Title: Obtenção de suco de caju atomizado através do controle das condições de secagem
Methodology: The study aimed to determine the best spray-drying conditions for producing cashew juice powder using a central composite rotational design. Physicochemical characterization was performed on both the integral cashew juice and the resulting juice powder.
Key Findings: The experimental design did not show significant differences at the 0.05 probability level, indicating that the model was not adjusted to the data, but an optimal process zone could be observed qualitatively. Key physicochemical parameters for the integral cashew juice and juice powder were reported, including moisture content, pH, titratable acidity, soluble solids, and vitamin C.

Authors: Bahare Salehi, Mine Gültekin‐Özgüven, Celale Kırkın, Beraat Özçelik, Maria Flaviana Bezerra Morais‐Braga, Joara Nályda Pereira Carneiro, Camila Fonseca Bezerra, Teresinha Gonçalves da Silva, Henrique Douglas Melo Coutinho, Amina Benabdallah, Lorene Armstrong, Zeliha Selamoğlu, Мustafa Sevindik, Zubaida Yousaf, Javad Sharifi‐Rad, Ali Mahmoud Muddathir, Hari Prasad Devkota, Miquel Martorell, Arun K. Jugran, Natália Martins, William C. Cho
Title: Anacardium Plants: Chemical,Nutritional Composition and Biotechnological Applications
Methodology: This review describes the habitat and cultivation of Anacardium species, phytochemical and nutritional composition, and their industrial food applications. It also discusses the secondary metabolites present in Anacardium plants and their antioxidant and antimicrobial effects.
Key Findings: Anacardium species contain rich secondary metabolites in their leaf and shoot powder, fruits and other parts that have shown diverse applications. The secondary metabolites display great antioxidant and antimicrobial effects. These characteristics make Anacardium species an interesting approach to the development of green foods in the food industry.

Authors: Ohoud Shami Al-sulbi, Amal Bakr Shori
Title: Viability of selected strains of probiotic Lactobacillus spp. and sensory evaluation of concentrated yogurt (labneh) made from cow, camel, and cashew milk
Methodology: The study investigated the effects of concentrated yogurt (labneh) made from cow, camel, and cashew milk and their mixtures using three strains of probiotic Lactobacillus spp. as starter cultures on post-acidification changes and the viability of lactic acid bacteria (LAB) during storage. Sensory evaluation of all yogurt samples was also conducted on the first day of storage.
Key Findings: The lowest pH was observed in Ew-/Ca-ML50%S3 and Ew-/Co-ML50%S3 during 21 days of storage. S. thermophilus increased to the highest numbers in Co-/Ca-ML50%S3 during the 7th and 14th day. All cashew milk labneh samples (EwML100%) were the most accepted by the panels.

Title: Métodos de redução da adstringência de pedúnculos de caju in natura e seus efeitos sobre a qualidade físico-química, nutricional e aromática
Methodology: The study investigated methods to reduce astringency in cashew apples using ethanol and carbon dioxide treatments, evaluating dosage, time, and temperature. It also tested different plastic films for passive modified atmosphere packaging.
Key Findings: Treatment with 3.5 mL ethanol per kg of cashew apple for 12 hours at 5°C effectively reduced astringency with minimal impact on nutritional quality and aroma. Applying 100% CO2 for 24 hours also reduced astringency without compromising physicochemical qualities. BOPP film (50 μm) was identified as the most suitable for astringency reduction and cashew apple preservation.
